skill.name: auth-implementation-patterns
skill.description: Master authentication and authorization patterns including JWT, OAuth2, session management, and RBAC to build secure, scalable access control systems. Use when implementing auth systems, securing APIs, or debugging security issues.
skill.summary: Master authentication and authorization patterns including JWT, OAuth2, session management, and RBAC...

security_audit.summary: The skill contains documentation and code examples only. No file access, network calls, or execution logic is present beyond illustrative snippets.

content.value_statement: You need clear guidance for secure authentication and authorization choices. This skill provides proven patterns and examples you can adapt quickly.
actual_capabilities: Explain JWT access and refresh token flows with validation steps
Show session-based authentication with Redis-backed storage
Outline OAuth2 social login setup with Passport strategies
Define RBAC and permission-based authorization middleware
Provide password hashing and rate limiting examples
limitations: No runnable project or full application scaffolding included
Does not provide database schemas or migration scripts
Does not implement MFA or device trust flows
Cloud provider specific configurations are not included

use_cases.title: Secure an API
use_cases.description: Choose and implement JWT or session auth with proper middleware and token handling.

use_cases.title: Add social login
use_cases.description: Integrate OAuth2 flows and redirect handling with clear examples.

use_cases.title: Audit auth design
use_cases.description: Check role and permission enforcement patterns against common pitfalls.

prompt_templates.title: Pick an auth approach
prompt_templates.scenario: New app needs login and API access
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend session or JWT auth for a small SaaS app. Include tradeoffs and a suggested default.

prompt_templates.title: Design refresh tokens
prompt_templates.scenario: Existing JWT setup lacks refresh logic
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a safe refresh token flow and storage guidance for a Node API.

prompt_templates.title: Add RBAC
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft RBAC middleware and role hierarchy for users, moderators, and admins.

prompt_templates.title: Harden login security
prompt_templates.scenario: Login endpoint is targeted by bots
prompt_templates.prompt: List concrete steps to secure login, including rate limiting and password policy.

output_examples.input: Design a secure JWT auth flow with refresh tokens for a REST API.
output: Use short lived access tokens and long lived refresh tokens stored hashed in the database
Verify refresh tokens on each rotation and revoke on logout
Attach user claims to the request after verification
Return 401 on expired or invalid tokens with clear error messages

best_practices: Keep access tokens short lived and refresh tokens hashed
Enforce strong password policies with bcrypt or argon2
Apply rate limits on authentication endpoints
anti_patterns: Storing JWTs in localStorage without XSS protections
Skipping token expiration or refresh rotation
Authorizing only on the client side

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Node and Express apps?
faq.answer: Yes, examples target Node and Express patterns, but concepts map to other stacks.

faq.question: What are the limits of the examples?
faq.answer: They are illustrative snippets and not a complete application or framework.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing auth providers?
faq.answer: Yes, the OAuth2 section shows provider based flows you can adapt.

faq.question: Does it collect or store user data?
faq.answer: No, it is documentation only and does not execute or transmit data.

faq.question: What should I check if tokens are rejected?
faq.answer: Verify secrets, token expiry, clock skew, and middleware parsing.

faq.question: How does this compare to a full auth library?
faq.answer: It explains patterns and tradeoffs, while libraries provide ready to use code.
